It's been just a few months since I've started studying NEAT and I'm
sorry if my question is very basic or has already been asked a lot of
times before (I've searched the group archive). I've been discussing
this with my friend and we don't understand how innovation numbers are
assigned to mutations.

Suppose a mutation links node n to node m. If another mutation linking
these nodes occurs in the same generation, they are both assigned the
same innovation number, this part was clear. But what if a mutation
linking the same nodes occurs 100 generations later? Is it assigned
the same innovation number or a different one?

I've read Stanley's original C++ code and it seems that the new
mutation is assigned a new innovation number, which makes sense to me,
because the two genes are not homologous and tracking homology among
genes is the whole point of innovation numbers, right? But looking at
a Python and a Java implementation, both have a global list of
mutations and will assign the same innovation number to a mutation
linking the same nodes. In this case, don't innovation numbers become
useless? All we need to know to align genes for reproduction is which
nodes are getting linked by a certain mutation. Also we could be
aligning genes that have completely different roles in completely
different network architectures. It seems wrong to me.

So does anyone know how this should be done and why?

Thanks,
Carolina
